Core Java

Below notes are based on the book OCP Oracle Certified Professional Java SE 17 Developer Study Guide.

1. Building Blocks​

Environment​

  1. JDK:
    Java Development Kit
    • javac: Convert .java (source file) into .class (bytecode)
    • java: Execute
    • jar: Package
    • javadoc: Document
  2. JRE:
    Java Runtime Environment
    • Subset of JDK
    • Cannot
      compile
  3. IDE:
    Integrated Development Environment

Class Structure​

Field and Method​

  1. Method
    : a.k.a. function or procedure in other languages
  2. Field
    : a.k.a. variable
  3. Method and Field are
    Members
    of a
    Class
    .
  4. void
    • Special return type
    • No value is returned
  5. Method Signature
    is the combination of method name and parameter types.

Classes and Source Files​

  1. Class is a
    Top level type
    .
  2. You can put two or more classes in a file.
  3. Within the file, at most one of the top level type is allowed to be public.
  4. If you have a public top level type, it must match the filename.

main() method​

  1. Method main() is for the execution of a program. 
    public static void main(String[] args)
    public static void main(String args[])
    public static void main(String... args)
    final public static void main(String... args)
    • public is an
      Access modifier
      .
    • static is used as no object needs to be created to run the program.
    • ... is called varargs
      Variable argument lists
      .
  2. Compile and run the program with commands below: 
    javac Test.java
    java Test
  3. File extention must be .java.
  4. The result of compilation is .class file, which is bytecode.
  5. Shortcut for running single file source code. 
    java Test.java
    • Skip explicit compilation step.
    • This feature is called launching single-file source code programs.
    • This feature is designed for scenario where your program is in one single file, such as unit testing.

Package and Import​

  1. Package
    is the logical grouping for classes.
  2. Package name is hierarchical, separated by period ..
    irushu.chapter1.Test1
    package irushu.chapter1;
    public class Test1 {
        public static void main(String... args){
            System.out.println("[START]");
            System.out.println("[CLASSNAME]" + Test1.class.getCanonicalName());
            System.out.println("[END]");
        }
    }
  3. Directory structure must follow the package name.
  4. Import
    statement tells which package to look in for classes. 
    import irushu.chapter1.Test1;
  5. Use wildcard to import all the classes of a package. 
    import irushu.chapter1.*;
  6. Wildcard can help shorten import list.
  7. Importing a lot of classes will not slow down execution time.
  8. Below are limitations for import statements.
    • Wildcard can only match class names. It
      cannot
      match directories or subdirectories.
    • There can only be 1 wildcard, and it must be placed at the end.
    • Import statement can only be used to match class names. It
      cannot
      match methods or fields.
  9. Naming conflicts
    • Class names don't have to be unique across all of the Java classes.
    • The same class name can be found in multiple places under different packages.
    • Explicitly importing a class name will take precedence over any wildcard present. 
      import java.util.Date; // This will win
      import java.sql.*;
    • In case you need a class name from 2 different packages, use fully qualified class name to declare the fields. 
      java.util.Date utilDate;
      java.sql.Date sqlDate;
  10. java.lang are automatically imported.
  11. Classes in the same package are automatically imported.

Compilation, Execution and JAR files​

  1. You can compile with command javac. 
    javac irushu/chapter1/Test1.java
    javac irushu/chapter1/*.java
    javac *.java // This will not compile any source file under package irushu.chapter1
  2. You can use -d to place class files in a different directory. 
    javac -d classes irushu/chapter1/Test1.java
  3. You can specify the classpath for required libraries to compile the program.
  4. You can specify the classpath and run the program with command java. 
    java -cp classes irushu.chapter1.Test1
    java -classpath classes irushu.chapter1.Test1
    java --class-path classes irushu.chapter1.Test1
  5. You can create jar file with command jar. 
    jar -cvf test.jar .
    jar -cvf test.jar -C classes . // -C specify the location that contains the class files
    jar --create --verbose --file test.jar .

Ordering elements in a class​

  • Elements should be ordered in a class as below.
    1. Package declaration
    2. Import statement
    3. Top level type declaration (Class / Interface / Enum)
    4. Field declaration
    5. Method declaration

Creating objects​

  1. You can define
    Constructor
    for the creation of a object.
  2. Below is an example of constructor. Note it does
    not
    have return type.
    irushu.chapter1.Test2
    package irushu.chapter1;
    public class Test2{
        public Test2(){
            // do something
        }
    }
  3. If you don't provide a constructor, compiler will supply a do nothing, no argument
    Default constructor
    for you.
  4. You can create object with the keyword new. 
    Test test = new Test();
  5. Caller can read and write instance variables directly.
    irushu.chapter1.Test3
    package irushu.chapter1;
    public class Test3{
        String helloWorld = "Hello World";
        public static void main(String... args){
            Test3 test = new Test3();
            System.out.println("cp1: " + test.helloWorld); // cp1: Hello World
            test.helloWorld = "Happy Valley";
            System.out.println("cp2: " + test.helloWorld); // cp2: Happy Valley
        }
    }
  6. However, you should honour encapsulation and protect instance variables with access modifier.
  7. You can define
    Instance initializer
    as below.
    irushu.chapter1.Test4
    package irushu.chapter1;
    public class Test4{
        {
            System.out.println("Test initializer");
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Test4 test = new Test4();
        }
    }
  8. Order of execution
    • Fields and Instance Initializer run in the order they appeared in the file.
    • Constructor
  9. Order matters and you can't refer to a variable before it has been defined.

Primitive Type and Literals​

  1. There are 8
    Primitive types
    .
    • byte (8), short (16), int (32), long (64)
      • Signed
      • Integral value
      • Each numeric type is twice the size as the smaller similar type.
    • float (32), double (64)
      • Signed
      • Floating point value
      • Each decimal type is twice the size as the smaller similar type.
    • char (16)
      • Unsigned
      • Unicode value
      • short and char values can be casted to one another as their underlying data size is the same.
    • boolean
      • bit size depends on JVM implementation
  2. When a number, decimal, String or character is present in the code, they are called
    Literals
    .
  3. By default java interprets numeric value as int.
  4. To specify the numeric literal as long, add l or L at the end of it.
  5. By default java interprets decimal value as double.
  6. To specify the decimal literal as float, add f or F at the end of it.
    irushu.chapter1.Test5
    float a = 2.0; // incompatible types: possible lossy conversion from double to float
    float b = 2.0f;
  7. Although float values can be declared with an f suffix, they are not printed with an f suffix.
    irushu.chapter1.Test6
    float b = 2.0f;
    System.out.println(b); // 2.0
  8. You can specify a number by changing base. By default it is using decimal number system.
    irushu.chapter1.Test7
    int a = 017; // Octal (0-7)
    int b = 0xFF; // Hexadecimal (0-9 a-f A-F)
    int c = 0B101; // Binary (0-1)
    System.out.println(a); // Print 15
    System.out.println(b); // Print 255
    System.out.println(c); // Print 5
  9. You can put underscores in numbers.
    irushu.chapter1.Test8
    int value = 1_000_000;
  10. You
    cannot
    put underscore at the beginning or end of a literal, or right before or after a decimal point.
    irushu.chapter1.Test9
    double a = _999.00; // Fail to compile
    double b = 999.00_; // Fail to compile
    double c = 999._00; // Fail to compile
    double d = 999_.00; // Fail to compile

Reference Type​

  1. A
    Reference type
    refers to an object.
  2. A reference points to an object by storing the memory address where the object is located.
  3. A reference is like a pointer.
  4. A reference can be assigned to another object.
  5. A reference can be assigned to a new object.

Primitive Type vs Reference Type​

  1. Primitive types have lowercase type names.
  2. Reference types have uppercase type names.
  3. Reference types can call methods.
  4. Primitive types do not have methods declared on them.
  5. If the value of a primitive type is unknown, you may assign null to its wrapper class.

Wrapper Class​

  1. Use valueOf to convert a String to its wrapper class.
  2. Use parseInt to convert a String to its primitive class.
    irushu.chapter1.Test10
    Integer a = Integer.valueOf("456"); // Wrapper
    int b = Integer.parseInt("789"); // Primitive
  3. Number classes, Boolean and Character Wrapper classes all have useful helper methods:
    • byteValue(), shortValue(), intValue(), longValue()
    • floatValue(), doubleValue()
    • booleanValue()
    • charValue()
  4. Helper classes try their best to convert values but may result in a loss of precision.

Text Block​

  1. """ as Start text block and End text block.
  2. Incidental whitespace
  3. Essential whitespace
  4. Escape characters

Declaring variables​

  1. Identifier
    is the name of a variable, method, class, interface, or package.
  2. Identifiers must begin with letter, a currency symbol or undercore symbol _ .
  3. Currency symbol includes dollar ($), yuan (¥), euro (€).
  4. A single underscore is
    not
    allowed.
  5. Cannot
    use reserve word.
  6. Cannot
    use literal values like true, false or null.

Case convention​

  1. Method or Field names are declared as lowercase camel case.
  2. Constants or enum values are declared as uppercase snake case.
  3. Class and Interface names are declared as uppercase camel case.

Declaring multiple variables​

irushu.chapter1.Test11
String str1, str2, str3="Foo";
int int1, float float1; // There can only be one type of declaration in a statement.
String str4, String str5; // You cannot repeat the same declaration in a statement, even they are the same.
double double1; double double2; // Semicolon separates statements, so there is no violation.
boolean boolean1; boolean2; // Invalid declaration for boolean2 as type is omitted.
  1. You can declare many variables in the same declaration as long as they are all of the same type.
  2. You
    cannot
    repeat the same declaration, even the declarations are of the same type.
  3. There can only be one declaration,
    no
    other declaration can be made.

Initializing variables​

  1. Local variable
    is a variable defined within a constructor, method, or initializer block.
  2. final modifier is equivalent to declaring constants.
  3. final modifier can apply to local variable.
  4. For final variable of primitive type, you
    cannot
    change its value once it is initialized.
  5. For final variable of reference type, you
    cannot
    change the reference, but you can modify the content the reference points to.
  6. Local variables do not have default value.
  7. Local variables must be initialized before use.
  8. For local variables that have never been used, compiler doesn't care if they are not initialized.
  9. Compiler is clever enough to determine whether the local variable has been used or not.
  10. If you pass uninitialized parameters to constructor or method, the program will fail to compile.
  11. Instance variable
    is a field defined within a specific instance of object.
  12. Class variable
    is defined on the class level and shared among all instances of the class.
  13. Both instance and class variables are given a default value once declared. You don't need to initialize them.
  14. Initialization of instance and class variables sticks to below rules.
    • null for an object
    • 0 for numeric types
    • 0.0 for decimal types
    • false for boolean
    • '\u000' for char
  15. Java does not support setting default method parameter values. Javascript does.
    Java does not support default parameter value
    public void method(int hello = 3){}
    Javascript supports default parameter value
    import React from 'react';
    export default function Highlight({children, color="#000000", fontWeight}) {
        return (
        <span
            style={{
            backgroundColor: color,
            borderRadius: '2px',
            color: '#fff',
            padding: '0.1rem',
            paddingLeft: '0.25rem',
            paddingRight: '0.25rem',
            marginLeft: '0.05rem',
            marginRight: '0.05rem',
            fontWeight: fontWeight,
            }}>
            {children}
        </span>
        );
    }
    To achieve default parameters, Java uses
    Overloading
    . 
    public void method(){
        method(3);
    }
    public void method(int hello){
        System.out.println(hello);
    }
    public static void main(String... args){
        method();
    }

Using var for local variable​

  1. You can use keyword var to declare local variables under certain circumstances.
  2. This feature is called
    Local variable type inference
    .
  3. var is only used for local variables.
  4. var will instruct the compiler to determine the type.
  5. In javascript, var can take on any type.
  6. But in java, compiler will determine the specific type for var. The type
    cannot
    be changed during runtime.
  7. var variable
    cannot
    be initialized to null during declaration. Compiler
    cannot
    infer its type.
  8. If the underlying type is a reference type, var variable can be reassigned with null value after declaration.
  9. var
    cannot
    be used in multiple variable assignment.
  10. For var, compiler will look only at the line of declaration. variable must be assigned values on the lines where they are defined. 
    void methodA(){
        var a = "String A";
        var b
            = 5;
        var c; // var variable is not assigned with values on the lines they are declared.
        c = 1;
        var d = null; // Compiler cannot infer the type
        var e = "String B";
        e = null;
        var f = 2, g = 2; // var cannot be used in multiple variable assignment
    }
  11. var
    cannot
    be used on method parameters. 
     void methodB(var a, var b){
     }
  12. var is not a reserved word and allowed to be used as an identifier. 
    void methodC(){
        var var = "hello"; // This will compile
    }

Variable scope​

  1. A set of braces means a new
    Code block
    .
  2. Each code block has its own scope.
  3. Code block can contain another code block.
  4. Inner block can reference variables of outer block, but not vice versa.
  5. Scope for different type of variables
    • Local variable: In scope from declaration to the end of the block.
    • Method parameters: In scope for the duration of the method.
    • Instance variable: In scope from declaration until the object is eligible for gc.
    • Class variable: In scope from declaration to end of the program.

Garbage collection​

  1. For
    Garbage collection
    , refer to JVM section.
  2. System.gc() is not guaranteed to do anything. JVM can ignore it.

2. Operators​

  1. An
    Operator
    is a special symbol or operation that can be applied to operands.
  2. An
    Operand
    is the variable / literal / value the operator being applied to.
  3. Unary, binary and tenary operator take 1, 2 and 3 operand(s) respectively.
  4. Evaluation can be left-to-right or right-to-left.
  5. Some operators require operand(s) of specific type.

Order of operator precedence​

  1. Operator should follow below orders.

    OperatorSymbolsEvaluation
    Post-unary operatorsexpression++, expression--LR
    Pre-unary operators++expression, --expressionLR
    Other unary operators-, !, ~, +, (type)Right-to-left
    Cast (Type)referenceRight-to-left
    Multiplication/division/modulus*, /, %LR
    Addition/subtraction+, -LR
    Shift operators<<,>>,>>>LR
    Relational operators<, >, <=, >=, instanceofLR
    Equal to/not equal to==, !=LR
    Logical AND&LR
    Logical exclusive OR^LR
    Logical inclusive OR|LR
    Conditional AND&&LR
    Conditional OR||LR
    Ternary operatorsboolean expression ? expression1 : expression2Right-to-left
    Assignment operators=, +=, -=, *=, /=, %=, &=, ^=, |=, <<=, >>=, >>>=Right-to-left
    Arrow operator->Right-to-left

Unary Operators​

  1. Requires exactly one operand to function.

    OperatorExamplesDescription
    Logical complement!aInverts a boolean's logical value
    Bitwise complement~bInverts all 0s and 1s in a number
    Plus+cIndicates a number is positive
    Negation or minus-dIndicates a literal number is negative or negates an expression
    Increment++e f++Increments a value by 1
    Decrement--f h--Decrements a value by 1

  2. Bitwise complement operator ( ~ )
    flips all 0s and 1s in a number.

  3. Bitwise complement operator can apply only on byte, short, int, long, char.

  4. You can use the formula bitwise complement = -1 * number value -1 to calculate the result for bitwise complement operation.

    irushu.chapter2.Test1
    int a = 7;
    System.out.println(~a); // Print -8. Because -1 * 7 - 1

  5. Negation operator ( - )
    reverses the sign of numeric expression.

  6. Negation operator can apply only on numeric expression.

  7. Increment and decrement operators ( ++ -- )
    can apply only on numeric variable.

  8. The order on how increment and decrement operators attached to the variable can change the behavior.

    • ++x / --y: increase / decrease by 1 and return the new value.
    • x++ / y--: increase / decrease by 1 but return the original value.
    irushu.chapter2.Test2
    int a = 1;
    System.out.println(++a); // print 2
    System.out.println(a++); // print 2
    System.out.println(a); // print 3

Binary Arithemtic Operators​

  1. Addition: a + b
  2. Subtraction: a - b
  3. Multiplication: a * b
  4. Division: a / b
  5. Modulus: a % b
  6. Arithmetic operators
    can apply on all primitives,
    except
    boolean.
  7. Addition operators ( + ) can apply on String for concatenation.
  8. You can change the precedence by wrapping with parentheses.
  9. Parentheses should be applied in a valid and balanced manner.
    • A new right parentheses match with a previous left parentheses
    • Equal number of left and right parentheses
  10. For integer values, division results in the floor value (value without anything after the decimal point) of the nearest integer that fulfills the operation.
    irushu.chapter2.Test3
    System.out.println( 13 / 4 ); // Prints 3

Numeric Promotion​

  1. Numeric
    Promotion rules
    • If two values have different data types, promote one of the values to the larger of the two data types.
      irushu.chapter2.Test4a
      int a = 1;
      long b = 2;
      var c = a + b; // a will be promoted to long. c will be long.
      System.out.println( ((Object)c).getClass().getSimpleName().toLowerCase() ); // long
    • If one is integral and the other is floating-point, promote the integral value to the floating-point value's data type.
      irushu.chapter2.Test4b
      int a = 1;
      float b = 2.1f;
      var c = a + b; // a will be promoted to float. c will be float.
      System.out.println( ((Object)c).getClass().getSimpleName().toLowerCase() ); // float
    • Smaller data types, namely, byte, short, and char, are first promoted to int, even if neither of the operands is int.
      irushu.chapter2.Test4c
      byte a = 1;
      short b = 2;
      var c = a + b; // a and b will be promoted to int. c will be int.
      System.out.println( ((Object)c).getClass().getSimpleName().toLowerCase() ); // integer
      • Unary operators are excluded from this rule.
    • Resulting value will have the same data type as its promoted operands.
  2. Be aware of the data type of variables, intermediate values, and resulting values

Assignment Operator​

  1. Assign variable on the left side with the result of the equation on the right side.
  2. Both the promotion rule and
    Casting
    will apply during assignment.
  3. Automatically promote from smaller to larger data type.
    irushu.chapter2.Test5
    short a = 10;
    byte b = 20;
    int c = a + b;
    long d = a + b;
    float e = a + b;
    double f = a + b;
    System.out.println(c); // Print 30
    System.out.println(d); // Print 30
    System.out.println(e); // Print 30.0
    System.out.println(f); // Print 30.0
  4. Compilation error will occur if you try to promote from larger to smaller data type without casting.
  5. Casting is a unary operation.
  6. Compiler automatically casts smaller types to larger ones.
  7. Casting is required when converting to smaller data type.
  8. Casting is performed by placing the data type, enclosed in parentheses, to the left of the value you want to cast.
    irushu.chapter2.Test6
    short a = 10; // Literals that fits to the data type does not need casting
    short b = 40000; // 40000 is larget than what the type short can hold. Compilation error occurs.
    short c = (short) 40000;
    System.out.println(c); // Overflow occur, print -25536.
    float d = 10;
    float e = (float) 10.0;
    float f = 10.0f;
    float g = 10.0;
  9. Casting can also be applied to object and reference.
  10. No conversion is performed for casting of object / reference.
  11. Casting an object only change the reference type of the object, not the object itself.
  12. Overflow
    occurs when a number is so large that it will no longer fit within the data type, so the system “wraps around” to the lowest negative value and counts up from there.
    irushu.chapter2.Test7a
    int a = (byte)( Byte.MAX_VALUE + 1 );
    System.out.println(a); // Print -128
  13. Underflow
    is an analogy to overflow when the number is too low to fit in the data type.
    irushu.chapter2.Test7b
    int a = (byte)( Byte.MIN_VALUE - 1 );
    System.out.println(a); // Print 127
  14. Casting can appear anywhere in an expression, not just an assignment.
  15. Compiler
    does not
    require casting when working with literals that fit into data types.
    irushu.chapter2.Test8
    byte a = 1;
    byte b = (byte) a * 2; // Because a is involved in the multiplication, third promotion rule applys, and a is casted to int during multiplication.
    byte c = 10 * 2; // Doesn't require casting
    byte d = 100 * 200;
    int e = 2 * 5.0;
    float f = 2 * 5.0;
    float g = 2 * 5.0f;
    double h = 2 * 5.0;
  16. When working with literal, the compiler has enough information for the programmer's intent. Casting is not required.
  17. When working with variable, there is ambiguity about how to proceed, and the compiler will throw error. Casting is required.
  18. Result of assignment for the expression is equal to the value of the assignment.
    irushu.chapter2.Test9
    int a = 5;
    int b = ( a = 10 ); // First 10 is assigned to a. Then the whole expression a = 10 returns 10.
    System.out.println(a); // Print 10
    System.out.println(b); // Print 10

Compound Assignment Operators​

  1. Addition assignment: a += 10
  2. Subtraction assignment: b -= 10
  3. Multiplication assignment: c *= 10
  4. Division assignment: d /= 10
  5. Compound assignment
    is a glorified form of simple assignment. It performs the following:
    • built-in operation that applies the left and right side of statement.
    • assigns the resulting value on the left side variable.
    • compiler will automatically perform casting during assignment.
    irushu.chapter2.Test10
        int a = 10;
        long b = 100;
        a = a * b; // Compilation error as long type is assigned to int type
        a = (int) a * b; // Compilation error as casting applied to a only, and then promotes to long again during multiplication
        a = (int) (a * b); // Explicit casting from long to int
        a *= b; // Implicit casting from long to int
In my opinion

The promotion rules and casting depicted above are not intuitive, and are therefore error-prone. In the first place, why do we perform operations of mixed data type? Avoid it at all cost. Second, casting from larger data type to smaller one doesn't make sense: Anything leading to a loss of precision, overflow or underflow is highly undesirable. Avoid it at all cost. Unless under extreme circumstances that saving memory space is crucial, always use large data type.

Equality Operators​

  1. Equality == and Inequality !=.
  2. For object type, we need to distinguish if
    • 2 objects are the same. (Using equality operator)
    • 2 objects are equivalent. (Using equals method)
  3. For object comparison, equality operator is applied to reference, not to the object that reference point to.
  4. For primitive type, there is no such distinction.
  5. Equality Operators must apply on the same type.
    irushu.chapter2.Test11
    int a = 1;
    float b = 2.0f;
    boolean c = true;
    String d = "true";
    int a1 = 1;
    float b1 = 3.0f;
    boolean c1 = true;
    System.out.println( a == b ); // Promotion rule to promote a to float
    System.out.println( b == c ); // Compilation error due to comparison between mixed type
    System.out.println( c == d ); // Compilation error due to comparison between mixed type
    System.out.println( a == a1 );
    System.out.println( b == b1 );
    System.out.println( c == c1 );
  6. Comparing null with null will return true in java.
    irushu.chapter2.Test12
    System.out.println( null == null ); // Print true

Relational Operators​

  1. >, >=, <, <=, instanceof
  2. Operator instanceof tests whether the target object is a member of a particular class or interface at runtime.
  3. If the compiler can determine that a variable
    cannot
    possibly be cast to a specific class, it reports an error.
    irushu.chapter2.Test13
    Integer x = 1;
    if(x instanceof String){}
  4. instanceof on a null literal / reference will always return false.
    irushu.chapter2.Test14
    String a = null;
    String b = "Hello World";
    System.out.println( null instanceof Object ); // Print false
    System.out.println( a instanceof String ); // Print false
    System.out.println( b instanceof Object ); // Print true
    System.out.println( b instanceof String ); // Print true
  5. null
    cannot
    be used on the right side of instanceof.
    irushu.chapter2.Test15
    String a = null;
    System.out.println( a instanceof null );

Logical Operator​

  1. Logical AND
    &: true when both operands are true.
  2. Logical OR
    |: true when at least one of operands is true.
  3. Logical XOR
    ^: true when operands are different to each other.

Conditional Operator​

  1. Conditional AND
    &&: true when both operands are true.
  2. Conditional OR
    ||: true when at least one of operands is true.
  3. Short circuit
    • For &&, if left side is false, right side will not be evaluated.
    • For ||, if left side is true, right side will not be evaluated.
  4. Avoid null pointer exception.
    irushu.chapter2.Test16
    String a = null;
    if( a != null && a.equals("Hello World")){} // Since a is null, it will short circuit immediately, and avoid NullPointerException on the right side    
    if( a != null & a.equals("Hello World")){} // Throw NullPointerException at runtime

Ternary Operator​

  1. (boolean expression)
    ?
    ( expression that returned if boolean is true )
    :
    ( expression that returned if boolean is false )
  2. Second and third expressions in ternary operations don't need to be the same data type.
    irushu.chapter2.Test17
    int a = 5;
    long b = 10;
    int c = (int)((true) ? b : a);
    System.out.println(c); // Print 10
  3. Second and third expressions must make sense for the data type. Compiler can detect wrong data type.
    irushu.chapter2.Test18
    int a = 5;
    int c = (int)((false) ? "Hello" : a);
  4. Only one of the expression on the right will be evaluated at runtime. Beware of unperformed side effect.

3. Control Flow Statement​

  1. Control Flow Statement
    breaks up the flow of execution by
    • Decision making
      (if, switch)
    • Looping
      (while, do/while, for, for-each)
    • Branching
      (Nested loop, continue, break, return)
  2. It allows selective execution for a particular segments of code.
  3. Target can be a single statement or block of statements.
  4. Using block is often preferred.

if statement​

  1. Java only accepts boolean expression, unlike other languages that accept 0 or 1.
  2. Remember to trace the open and close braces of a block.

Pattern matching (Java 14)​

  1. Java 16 introduces
    Pattern matching
    for if statement using instanceof operator.
    if statement
    if(baobao instanceof Dog){
        Dog dog = (Dog) baobao;
        dog.bark();
    }
    if statement (With pattern matching)
    if(baobao instanceof Dog dog ){
        dog.bark();
    }
  2. Unrelated to regular expression.
  3. Enhancement to reduce boilerplate code by introducing implicit type casting.
  4. From the above example, dog is the
    Pattern variable
    .
  5. Avoid potential ClassCastException because type casting is performed only if the instanceof statement is true.
  6. It is a bad practice to reassign the pattern variable. Prevent reassignment by final modifier. 
    if(baobao instanceof Dog dog ){
        dog = new SmallDog(); // Bad practice to reassign the pattern variable.
    }
    if(baobao instanceof final Dog dog ){ // Prevent reassignment by final modifier
        // Do something
    }
  7. We can include && statement with pattern variable that declared on the same line to filter data out. 
    if(baobao instanceof final Dog dog 
        && dog.getAge() > 10 ){
        // Do something
    }
  8. Pattern variable must be a strict subtype. Even the same type is
    not
    allowed. 
    Integer a = 1000;
    if(a instanceof Integer b){} // Same type is not allowed!
  9. Flow scoping
    means the variable is in scope only when the compiler can definitely determine its type.
  10. Not strictly hierarchical like instance, class or local scoping.
  11. Even if the variable is not inside the if statement, it can still be deemed in scope by the compiler. 
    void test(Number number) { 
        if (!(number instanceof Integer data))
            return;
        System.out.println(data.intValue()); // Compiler determines the data variable in this line is in scope
    }
    Here, the System.out.println statement is not within if statement. However the compiler determines it is in scope as the instanceof operator returns true for that area.
  12. Pattern matching is quite different from other scoping. It is not determined hierarchically by whether the variable is within a pair of braces. It is determined by compiler whether the area is in scope.

switch statement​

  1. If no such case is found, the default case will be called. If default case is not provided, the whole switch block will be simply skipped. 
    int a = 999;
    switch(a){
        case 1: 
            System.out.println("1");
            break;    
        default: 
            System.out.println("0");
            break;
    }
    Result
    0
  2. A break statement ends the switch statement immediately. 
    int a = 3;
    switch(a){
        case 1: 
            System.out.println("1");
            break;
        case 2: 
            System.out.println("2");
            break;    
        case 3: 
            System.out.println("3");
            break;
        default: 
            System.out.println("0");
            break;
    }
    Result
    3
  3. Without break statement, it will match the first case statement, and executes all of the branches in the order they are found. 
    int a = 3;
    switch(a){
        case 1: System.out.println("1");
        case 2: System.out.println("2");    
        case 3: System.out.println("3");
        default: System.out.println("0");  
        case 5: System.out.println("5");  
        case 4: System.out.println("4");  
    }
    Result
    3
    0
    5
    4
  4. Starting with Java 14, case value can be combined.
    Prior to Java 14
    int a = 2;
    switch(a){
        case 1: case 2: 
            System.out.println(" 1 or 2 ");
            break;
        case 3: 
            System.out.println(" 3 ");
            break;
        default: 
            System.out.println(" Default ");
            break;
    }
    Starting with Java 14
    int a = 2;
    switch(a){
        case 1, 2: 
            System.out.println(" 1 or 2 ");
            break;
        case 3: 
            System.out.println(" 3 ");
            break;
        default: 
            System.out.println(" Default ");
            break;
    }
  5. switch supports the following data type.
    • byte, short, int
    • char, String
    • enum values
  6. boolean, long, float, double are not supported because their range of values are either too narrow or wide.
  7. case value must be compile time constant expression. If the case value
    cannot
    be evaluated until runtime, it will fail the compilation. 
    static int getValue(){
        return 2;
    }
    public static void main(String... args) {
        int a = 2;
        final int CASE_1 = 1;
        final int CASE_2 = getValue();
        switch(a){
            case CASE_1:
                System.out.println(" 1 ");
                break;
            case CASE_2:
                System.out.println(" 2 ");
                break;
            default:
                System.out.println(" Default ");
                break;
        }
    }
  8. case value supports only
    • literals
    • enum constants
    • final constants

switch expression (Java 14)​

  1. Starting with Java 14,
    Switch expression
    is supported. 
    byte a = 2;
    byte b = 4;
    byte c = switch (a) {
        case 1 -> 0; // expression
        case 2, 3 -> { // block
            if (b == 4) {
                yield 10;
            } else {
                yield 20;
            }
        }
        default -> 99;
    };
    System.out.println(c);
    Result
    10
  2. It is a compact form of switch statement.
  3. It can return a value.
  4. It supports both expression and block.
  5. Keyword yield (exit the switch block) is provided to distinguish it from the keyword return (exit the method).
  6. break statement is not required. Only one branch will be executed.
  7. Each case or default expression requires a semicolon as well as the assignment itself.
  8. It is allowed that switch expression doesn't return a value. 
    byte a = 3;
    switch(a){
        case 1 -> System.out.println("1");
        case 2 -> System.out.println("2");
        case 3 -> System.out.println("3");
        default -> System.out.println("default"); // Default case is optional in this case
    }
  9. If the switch expression returns value, all of the branches must either return a value (expression) or yield a value (block).
  10. If the switch expression returns value, all possible case values have to be covered. You can either
    • provide a default branch.
    • or cover all possible values. Though quite impossible unless it is a enum type.
  11. If the switch expression returns value, all case and default branches must return a consistent and compatible data type.

while statement​

do while statement​

  1. Guarantee the statement or block inside will be run once.

for loop​

  1. Infinite loop is allowed. 
    for(;;){
        System.out.println("Hello World.");
        break;
    }
  2. Multiple variables are allowed. 
    for(int x=0 , y=10; x<20 || y>=0; x++, y--){
        System.out.println("x="+x);
        System.out.println("y="+y);
    }
  3. Variables must all be of the same type and declared once. 
    for(int x=0 , long y=10; x<20 || y>=0; x++, y--){
        System.out.println("x="+x);
        System.out.println("y="+y);
    }

    for(int x=0 , int y=10; x<20 || y>=0; x++, y--){
        System.out.println("x="+x);
        System.out.println("y="+y);
    }
  4. Using variable outside the loop is not allowed. The variable is only scoped for the loop. 
    for(int x=0 , y=10; x<20 || y>=0; x++, y--)
        System.out.println("x="+x);
    System.out.println("y="+y);

for each loop​

  1. The right side must be:
    • built-in Java array.
    • an object that implements java.lang.Iterable.
  2. Not all Collection Framework classes implements java.lang.Iterable.
  3. Map does not implement java.lang.Iterable. However, the collection that its methods such as values() and keySet() returns does. 
    Map<String, Integer> map = new HashMap<String, Integer>();
    map.put("one", 1);
    map.put("two", 2);
    for(String key: map.keySet()){
        System.out.println(key);
    }
    for(Integer value: map.values()){
        System.out.println(value);
    }

Branching​

Nested Loop​

  1. A loop can contain another loop. This is called nested loop.

Optional label​

  1. if, switch and for loop can all have optional labels on their block and control statements.
  2. Optional label is not good for readability. Use only when necessary.

break statement​

  1. Break statement breaks the loop early. The loop terminates immediately. There will be no further iteration.
  2. For nested loops, without a label, the break statement will terminate the latest inner loop. 
    for(int i=0 ; i<10; i++){
        for(int j=0 ; j<10; j++){
            System.out.println( i + j );
            if (i==j)
                break;
        }
    }
  3. For nested loops, with an optional label, it makes the break statement possible to break out a higher level outer loop. 
    OUTER_LOOP: for(int i=0 ; i<10; i++){
        INNER_LOOP: for(int j=0 ; j<10; j++){
            System.out.println( i + j );
            if (i==j)
                break OUTER_LOOP;
        }
    }

continue statement​

  1. Continue statement ends the current iteration of the loop. It will skip the current iteration of the loop. It will continue to run the remaining iterations of the loop.
  2. For nested loops, without a label, the continue statement will end the current iteration of the inner loop.
  3. For nested loops, with an optional label, the continue statement can end the current iteration of higher level outer loop.

return statement​

  1. When the loop is inside a method, return statement can be used to exit the loop early, instead of using break statement with optional label. 
    for(int i=0 ; i<10; i++){
        for(int j=0 ; j<10; j++){
            System.out.println( i + j );
            if (i==j)
                return;
        }
    }
  2. Code without break statements and labels are easier to read.

Unreachable Code​

  1. Any code placed immediately after break, continue, return will be deemed unreachable by compiler.

Support for labels, break, continue and yield​

  1. yield can only be used in switch expression.
  2. continue can only be used in loop statement.
  3. break and optional labels can be used in switch and loop statements.

4. Core APIs​

String​

  1. A sequence of characters which counts from 0 when indexed.
  2. Doesn't need to be instantiated with the keyword new.
  3. Text block can create String. 
    String hello = """
                    Hello World""";
  4. Implements the interface CharSequence.
  5. Rules for + operator.
    • When both operands are numeric, + means addition.
    • If either one is String, + means concatenation.
    • Expression is evaluated from left to right.
    • During concatenation, a null value will be represented by the string null.
    System.out.println( 10 + 100 ); // 110
    System.out.println( 12 + "345" ); // 12345
    System.out.println( "543" + 12 ); // 54321
    System.out.println( "654" + 32 + 1 ); // 654321
    System.out.println( 12 + 3 + "456" ); // 15456 
    System.out.println( 1 + null ); // compile error
    System.out.println( "1" + null ); // 1null
    String a = null;
    String b = null;
    System.out.println( a + b ); // nullnull
  6. a += "1" means a = a + "1".
  7. String is immutable.
  8. Calling a method on String will return a different String object.
  9. Illustration of String methods. 
    String stringA = "Hello World";
    // length
    System.out.println( stringA.length() ); // 11
    // charAt
    System.out.println( stringA.charAt(0) ); // H
    System.out.println( stringA.charAt(10) ); // d
    try{
        System.out.println( stringA.charAt(11) ); // Runtime error: java.lang.StringIndexOutOfBoundsException
    }
    catch (Exception e){
        System.out.println(e);
    }
    // indexOf
    System.out.println( stringA.indexOf('l') ); // 2
    System.out.println( stringA.indexOf("l") ); // 2
    // subString
    System.out.println( stringA.substring(6) ); // World
    System.out.println( stringA.substring(0,2) ); // He
    // toLowerCase, toUpperCase
    System.out.println( stringA.toLowerCase() ); // hello world
    System.out.println( stringA.toUpperCase() ); // HELLO WORLD
    // equals, equalIgnoreCase
    System.out.println( stringA.toLowerCase().equals(stringA) ); // false
    System.out.println( stringA.toLowerCase().equalsIgnoreCase(stringA.toUpperCase()) ); // true
    // startsWith, endsWith, contains
    System.out.println( stringA.startsWith("Hello")); // true
    System.out.println( stringA.endsWith("World")); // true
    System.out.println( stringA.contains("o W")); // true
    // replace
    System.out.println( stringA.replace('H', 'h').replace('W','w')); // hello world
    System.out.println( stringA.replace("Hello", "Happy")); // Happy World
    // isEmpty, isBlank
    System.out.println(" ".isEmpty()); // false
    System.out.println("".isEmpty());  // true
    System.out.println(" ".isBlank()); // true
    System.out.println("".isBlank());  // true
    // trim, strip, stripLeading, stripTrailing
    System.out.println( "  Hello World   ".trim()); // "Hello World"
    System.out.println( "  Hello World   ".strip()); // "Hello World"
    System.out.println( "  Hello World   ".stripLeading()); // "Hello World   "
    System.out.println( "  Hello World   ".stripTrailing()); // "   Hello World"
    info

    Difference between strip() and trim()

    Run to see the indentation
    // indent
    var stringX = """
                    Hello
                     World""";
    System.out.println(stringX);
    System.out.println(stringX.length()); // 12
    System.out.println(stringX.indent(0));
    System.out.println(stringX.indent(0).length()); // 13
    System.out.println(stringX.indent(1));
    System.out.println(stringX.indent(1).length()); // 15
    System.out.println(stringX.indent(-1));
    System.out.println(stringX.indent(-1).length()); // 12
    Run to see the indentation
    // stripIndent
    var stringY = " Hello\n" +
                  " World\n" +
                  " !";
    System.out.println(stringY);
    System.out.println(stringY.length()); // 16
    System.out.println(stringY.stripIndent());
    System.out.println(stringY.stripIndent().length()); // 13
    // translateEscapes
    var stringA = " Hello\\n" +
                  " World\\n" +
                  " !";
    System.out.println(stringA);
    System.out.println(stringA.translateEscapes());
    Result
    Hello\n World\n !
    Hello
    World
    !
    // format, formatted
    var stringA = "Hello World";
    var integerB = 123;
    var doubleC = 456.0;
    System.out.println( String.format("%s%n integerB=%d%n doubleC=%f", stringA, integerB, doubleC));
    System.out.println( "%s%n integerB=%d%n doubleC=%f".formatted( stringA, integerB, doubleC));
    Result
    Hello World
     integerB=123
     doubleC=456.000000
    Hello World
     integerB=123
     doubleC=456.000000

StringBuilder​

  1. StringBuilder is not immutable.
  2. Concatenation of String will result in a lot of interim String objects, which are immediately available for GC.
    Below code will create 27 objects.
    String str = "";
    for(char i='a'; i<='z'; i++)
        str += i;
    System.out.println(str);
  3. Concatenation of String via StringBuilder will not result in any interim object.
    Below code will create only the StringBuilder object.
    StringBuilder stringBuilder = new StringBuilder("");
    for(char i='a'; i<='z'; i++)
        stringBuilder.append(i);
    System.out.println(stringBuilder.toString());
  4. substring() returns a String instead of StringBuilder. No modification is ever made to the original StringBuilder. 
    // substring
    StringBuilder stringBuilder = new StringBuilder("Hello World");
    String substring = stringBuilder.substring(0,4);
    System.out.println(substring); // Hell
    System.out.println(stringBuilder.toString()); // Hello World
  5. Some common methods as below: 
    var stringBuilder = new StringBuilder("Hello World");
    // length
    System.out.println(stringBuilder.length()); // 11
    // indexOf
    System.out.println(stringBuilder.indexOf("l")); // 2
    // charAt
    System.out.println(stringBuilder.charAt(4)); // o
    // insert, append
    System.out.println(stringBuilder.insert(0,'(').append(')')); // (Hello World)
    // delete, deleteCharAt
    System.out.println(stringBuilder.delete(0,1).deleteCharAt(stringBuilder.length()-1)); // Hello World
    // replace
    System.out.println(stringBuilder.replace(0,5,"Happy")); // Happy World
    // reverse, toString
    System.out.println(stringBuilder.reverse().toString().toUpperCase()); // DLROW YPPAH

Equality​

  1. Operator == checks object reference equality.
  2. By default, equals() checks object reference equality.
  3. equals() of StringBuilder checks object reference equality. 
    var a1 = new StringBuilder("Hello World");
    var a2 = new StringBuilder("Hello World");
    System.out.println(a1.equals(a2)); // false
    System.out.println(a1 == a2); // false
  4. equals() of String is overridden, and checks value equality. 
    var a1 = "Hello World";
    var a2 = "Hello World";
    System.out.println(a1.equals(a2)); // true
    System.out.println(a1 == a2); // true
  5. String literal is pooled in
    String Pool
    . 
    var a1 = "Hello World";
    var a2 = "Hello World";
    var a3 = "Hello" + " " + "World";
    var a4 = "Hello World".trim();
    var a5 = " Hello World ".trim();
    System.out.println(a1 == a2); // true
    System.out.println(a1 == a3); // true
    System.out.println(a1 == a4); // true
    System.out.println(a1 == a5); // false
  6. For String that are not the same at compile time, a new String object is created. 
    var a1 = "Hello World";
    var a2 = "Hello";
    a2 += " World";
    System.out.println(a1 == a2); // false
  7. intern() will return the String from the String Pool (if exist) instead of creating a new String. 
    var a1 = "Hello World";
    var a2 = "Hello";
    a2 += " World";
    a2 = a2.intern();
    System.out.println(a1 == a2); // true
  8. intern() should only be used in the exam.

Array​

  1. An area of memory on the heap with space for a designated number of elements.
  2. Both String and StringBuilder are implemented as array.
  3. For String, method is provided to handle characters specifically.
  4. For StringBuilder, array object is replaced with bigger array object when running out of space.
  5. An array is an ordered list.
  6. Declaration 
    int[] a1;
    int [] a2;
    int []a3;
    int a4[];
    int a5 [];
    // Multiple declaration
    int[] a6, a7; // 2 int array
    int a8, a9[] // 1 int, 1 int[]
  7. Instantiation and initialization 
    int[] a = new int[] { 1, 2, 3};
    int[] b = { 1, 2, 3 };
  8. equals() of array checks reference equality. 
    Integer[] a = { 1, 2, 3 };
    Integer[] b = a;
    System.out.println(a.equals(b)); // true
    System.out.println(a); // [Ljava.lang.Integer;@7a4f0f29
    // [L means array.
    // java.lang.Integer is the reference type.
    // 7a4f0f29 is the hash code
    System.out.println(Arrays.toString(a)); // [1, 2, 3]
  9. Casting to force bigger type to smaller type. 
    String[] strings1 = { "Happy Valley" };
    Object[] objects = strings1;
    String[] strings2 = (String[]) objects;
    objects[0] = new StringBuilder("Hello World"); // java.lang.ArrayStoreException
  10. Some common methods 
    String[] friends = { "Mary", "Cindy", "Amy"};
    System.out.println(friends.length); // 3
    System.out.println(friends.length()); // Compilation Error
    System.out.println(friends[0]); // Mary
    System.out.println(friends[3]); // ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
  11. length attribute does not consider what is in the array. It only considers how many slots have been allocated. 
    String[] friends = new String[3];
    System.out.println(friends.length); // 3
    System.out.println(friends[0]); // null
  12. sort 
    String[] friends = { "Mary", "Cindy", "Amy"};
    System.out.println(Arrays.toString(friends)); // [Mary, Cindy, Amy]
    Arrays.sort(friends);
    System.out.println(Arrays.toString(friends)); // [Amy, Cindy, Mary]
  13. binarySearch
    • Prerequisite: the array should be sorted beforehand, or unknown result will be returned.
    • Found: return index.
    • Not Found: -(Index of larger and nearest match) -1 .
    int[] a = { 10, 50, 100, 1000, 10000};
    System.out.println(Arrays.binarySearch(a, 10)); // 0
    System.out.println(Arrays.binarySearch(a, 100)); // 2
    System.out.println(Arrays.binarySearch(a, 999)); // -4
    System.out.println(Arrays.binarySearch(a, 5000)); // -5
    System.out.println(Arrays.binarySearch(a, 9999)); // -5
  14. compare for number
    • same length, same elements => 0
    • same elements, but more element at the end of first array => +
    • same elements, but more element at the end of second array => -
    • first element is larger in the first array => +
    • first element is larger in the second array => -
    int[] a1 = { 1, 3, 5, 7, 9};
    int[] a2 = { 1, 3, 5, 7, 9};
    int[] b1 = { 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11};
    int[] b2 = { 1, 3, 5, 7};
    int[] c1 = { 2, 2, 2, 2, 2};
    int[] c2 = { 1, 2, 2, 2, 2};
    int[] c3 = { 1, 4, 2, 2, 2};
    int[] c4 = { 1, 1, 1, 1};
    int[] c5 = { 1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1};
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a1, a2)); // 0
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a1, b1)); // -1
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a1, b2)); // 1
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a1, c1)); // -1
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a1, c2)); // 1
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a1, c3)); // -1
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a1, c4)); // 1
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a1, c5)); // 1
  15. compare for string
    • null is smaller
    • uppercase is smaller than lowercase
    • number is smaller than letter
    String[] a = { "a" };
    String[] A = { "A" };
    String[] b = { "b" };
    String[] B = { "B" };
    String[] c_s = { "c" , "C" };
    String[] z = { "z" };
    String[] NULL = { null };
    String[] NUMBER = { "0" };
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a, A)); // 32
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a, b)); // -1
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a, B)); // 31
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(z, c_s)); // 23
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a, NULL)); // 1
    System.out.println(Arrays.compare(a, NUMBER)); // 49
  16. mismatch
    • the same => -1
    • not the same => the first index they differ
    int[] a1 = { 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 };
    int[] a2 = { 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 };
    int[] b1 = { 0, 2, 4, 6, 8 };
    int[] b2 = { 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 };
    int[] c1 = { 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11};
    int[] c2 = { 1, 3, 5, 7};
    System.out.println(Arrays.mismatch(a1, a2)); // -1
    System.out.println(Arrays.mismatch(a1, b1)); // 0
    System.out.println(Arrays.mismatch(a1, b2)); // 0
    System.out.println(Arrays.mismatch(a1, c1)); // 5
    System.out.println(Arrays.mismatch(a1, c2)); // 4
  17. Multi-dimensional array 
    // 2D array
    int[][] a = {{ 1, 3, 5, 7, 9 }, { 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 }};
    int[] b[] = new int[5][5];
    // 3D array
    int[] c[][];
    // Asymmetric array
    int[] []d = new int[2][];
    d[0] = new int[3];
    d[1] = new int[6];
    // for loop
    for(int i=0; i<a.length; i++){
        for(int j=0; j<a[i].length; j++){
            System.out.print(a[i][j]); // 13579246810
        }
    }
    System.out.println("");
    // for each loop
    for(int[] outer: a){
        for(int inner: outer){
            System.out.print(inner); // 13579246810
        }
    }

Math API​

  1. https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.base/java/lang/Math.html
  2. Perform basic numeric operations such as the elementary exponential, logarithm, square root, and trigonometric functions.
  3. Fields and some methods 
    static final double E // Base of natural logarithms
    static final double PI // ratio of circumference of a circle to its diameter
    public static double min(double a, double b)
    public static float min(float a, float b)
    public static int min(int a, int b)
    public static long min(long a, long b)
    public static long round(double num)
    public static int round(float num)
    public static double ceil(double num)
    public static double floor(double num)
    public static double pow(double number, double exponent)
    public static double random()

Date and Time​

  1. 3 things: Date, Time and Timezone.
    1. LocalDate
       contains Date only.
    2. LocalTime
       contains Time only.
    3. LocalDateTime
       contains Date and Time only.
    4. ZonedDateTime
       contains Date, Time and Timezone.
    System.out.println(LocalDate.now()); // 2023-10-07
    System.out.println(LocalTime.now()); // 14:34:07.333623
    System.out.println(LocalDateTime.now()); // 2023-10-07T14:34:07.333692
    System.out.println(ZonedDateTime.now()); // 2023-10-07T14:34:07.333956+08:00[Asia/Hong_Kong]
  2. Timezone offset can be listed as +08:00, GMT+8 or UTC+8.
  3. Static factory method of 
    public static LocalDate of(int year, int month, int dayOfMonth)
    public static LocalDate of(int year, Month month, int dayOfMonth)
    public static LocalTime of(int hour, int minute)
    public static LocalTime of(int hour, int minute, int second)
    public static LocalTime of(int hour, int minute, int second, int nanos)
    public static LocalDateTime of(int year, int month, int dayOfMonth, int hour, int minute)
    public static LocalDateTime of(int year, int month, int dayOfMonth, int hour, int minute, int second)
    public static LocalDateTime of(int year, int month, int dayOfMonth, int hour, int minute, int second, int nanos)
    public static LocalDateTime of(int year, int month, int dayOfMonth, int hour, int minute)
    public static LocalDateTime of(int year, int month, int dayOfMonth, int hour, int minute, int second)
    public static LocalDateTime of(int year, int month, int dayOfMonth, int hour, int minute, int second, int nanos)
  4. plus and minus method 
    plusYears()
    minusYears()
    plusMonths()
    minusMonths()
    plusWeeks()
    minusWeeks()
    plusDays()
    minusDays()
    plusHours()
    minusHours()
    plusMinutes()
    minusMinutes()
    plusSeconds()
    minusSeconds()
    plusNanos()
    minusNanos()
  5. Period
     class 
    var date = ZonedDateTime.now();
    System.out.println(date); // 2023-10-07T14:48:31.417133+08:00[Asia/Hong_Kong]
    var period = Period.ofMonths(2);
    date.plus(period);
    System.out.println(date); // 2023-12-07T14:48:31.417133+08:00[Asia/Hong_Kong]
  6. Period supports years, months, weeks and days.
  7. Period.of takes only year, months and days, without weeks.
  8. Be aware of using invalid period on objects. For example, time has no years, months or days. 
    var period = Period.of(1, 2, 3); // 1 year 2 months 3 days
    var zonedDateTime = ZonedDateTime.now();
    var localTime = LocalTime.now();
    zonedDateTime = zonedDateTime.plus(period);
    localTime = localTime.plus(period); // java.time.temporal.UnsupportedTemporalTypeException: Unsupported unit: Months
  9. Duration
     class is for smaller units of time.
  10. Duration supports days, hours, minutes, seconds, milliseconds and nanoseconds.
  11. Duration doesn't have a factory method that takes multiple units like Period.of.
  12. Duration has a generic factory method that takes
    ChronoUnit
    . 
    var dateTime = LocalDateTime.now();
    System.out.println(dateTime); // 2023-10-07T15:11:07.554493
    var halfDay = Duration.of(4, ChronoUnit.HALF_DAYS);
    dateTime = dateTime.plus(halfDay);
    System.out.println(dateTime); // 2023-10-09T15:11:07.554493
  13. LocalDate, LocalTime, LocalDateTime, ZoneDateTime are temporal.
  14. ChronoUnit can tell the time gap between 2 temporals. 
    var date1 = LocalDateTime.of( 2023, 10, 7, 0, 0);
    var date2 = LocalDateTime.of( 2023, 10, 17, 0, 0);
    System.out.println(ChronoUnit.DAYS.between(date1, date2)); // 10
  15. ChronoUnit is in the java.time.Temporal package.
  16. Duration can only be used with object with time.
  17. Period can only be used with object with date.
  18. Instant
     specifies moment in GMT time zone. 
    System.out.println(ZonedDateTime.now()); // 2023-10-07T15:25:59.475706+08:00[Asia/Hong_Kong]
    System.out.println(ZonedDateTime.now().toInstant()); // 2023-10-07T07:25:59.475894Z
    System.out.println(Instant.now()); // 2023-10-07T07:25:59.477320Z
  19. Daylight Saving Time.
    1. March forwards from 1:59 am to 3:00 am. (Skip the hour, so 2:30 am doesn't exist)
    2. November falls back and experience hour 1:00 am to 1:59 am twice. (Repeat the hour)

5. Methods​

Introduction​

  1. A method consists of the following. Bolded elements are mandatory.
    • Access modifier
    • Optional specifier
    • Return type
    • Method name
    • Parameter list
    • Method Signature (Method name + Parameter list)
    • Exception List
    • Method body (Except for abstract method)
  2. Access modifier and optional specifier can appear in any order.
  3. Access modifier and optional specifier must all appear before return type.

Access Modifier
​

  1. private - same class
    tip

    The access is on the class itself. Even if 2 classes are defined in the same java file, they

    cannot
    access private fields or methods of each other.

  2. package - same package, default access, no keyword
  3. protected - same package or subclass.
    • There are 2 ways to access protected members.
      • via inheritance, easy to understand
      • via variable, i.e. reference type of the variable, check the relationship between the current class and the variable, whether they are of the same package or the current class is a subclass of the variable reference type
      class Child extends Parent{
          public Child(){
              System.out.println(whatIsProtected); // via inheritance
          }
      }
      class Peer{
          void createParent(){
              Parent parent = new Parent();
              System.out.println(parent.whatIsProtected); // via variable
          }
      }
      public class Parent {
          protected String whatIsProtected= "Only for same package and subclass Here";
          public static void main(String... args) {
              Child child = new Child(); // Only for same package and subclass
              Peer peer = new Peer();
              peer.createParent(); // Only for same package and subclass
          }
      }
    • Please refer to book examples.
  4. public - Anyone

Optional Specifier
​

  1. static, abstract, final, default, synchronized, native, strictfp
  2. Some specifiers are not compatible with one another.
  3. You can't declare a method final and abstract.

Return Type
​

  1. Appear after access modifier or optional specifier.
  2. Appear before method name.
  3. If there is no return type, use the keyword void.
  4. Methods with a return type other than void must have a return statement inside the method body.
  5. Methods with return type void can either skip the return statement, or include return statement with no value returned.

Method Name
​

  1. Review the section Building Blocks > Declaring variables for restrictions and convention for an identifier.

Parameter List
​

  1. Required but doesn't have to contain any parameters.
  2. Separate multiple parameters with comma.

Method Signature
​

  1. Composed of method name and parameter list.
  2. Names of the parameters are not used as a part of a method signature.
  3. Method signature only cares about the type and order of parameters in a parameter list.
  4. Java uses it to uniquely identify which method you are trying to call.

Exception List
​

Method Body
​

  1. a code block with return statement.
  2. requires to have a body unless declared abstract.

Local variables and Instance variables​

  1. Local variables are defined in a method or code block.
  2. Instance variables are defined as a member of a class.
  3. Only final modifier can be applied to local variables.
  4. For final primitives, once it is assigned, its value
    cannot
    be modified.
  5. For final object, once it is assigned, its reference
    cannot
    be modified. Its content can however be modified.
  6. Effectively final
    means the variable is not modified after assignment, even if it is not marked as final. Compiler can detect it.
  7. Local classes and lambda expressions declared within a method can only reference local variables that are final or effectively final.
  8. Access modifier can be applied to instance variables.
  9. Optional specifier final, transient, volatile can be applied to instance variables.
  10. Compiler does not apply default value to final instance or class variables.
  11. If instance variables are marked final, they must be assigned a value when it is declared or when the object is instantiated (Either in constructor or initializer).

Methods with Varargs​

  1. A method may use a varargs parameter with below rules:
    • It can have at most 1 varargs parameter.
    • Varargs parameter must be the last parameter.
    static void method(String... p1) {};
    static void method(String p1, String... p2) {};
    static void method(String... p1, String p2) {}; // violation: Last parameter
    static void method(String... p1, String... p2) {}; // violation: At most 1 varargs parameter
  2. When calling method, you can either:
    • pass in an array
    • or list the elements and let Java create for you
    static void print(String... names) {
        for(String name : names) System.out.println(name);
    }
    public static void main(String... args) {
        print( new String[]{"Mary", "Cindy", "Amy"} ); // pass in array
        print("June", "Jane", "Becky"); // list the elements
    }
  3. The method will receive the array containing the elements.
  4. Java will create an array of length 0 if varargs is omitted. 
    static void print(String... names) {
       System.out.println(names.length);
    }
    public static void main(String... args) {
        print(); // 0
    }
  5. Accessing a varargs parameter is like accessing array. It has the same array indexing.
  6. If passing null to varargs parameter, java will treat it as array reference and result in NullPointerException. 
    static void print(String... names) {
        System.out.println(names.length);
    }
    public static void main(String... args) {
        print(null); // java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot read the array length because "a" is null
    }

static​

  1. static can be applied to class, method and variable.
  2. static can be applied to import statement.
  3. The target will then belong to the class rather than a specific instance of the class.
  4. Static methods have 2 main purpose.
    • Utility / Helper methods that don't require any object state.
    • For state(s) that is/are shared by all instances.
  5. You can use an instance of the class to call the static method. The compiler checks for the type of the reference and uses that instead of the object. 
    public class Test {
        public static String everyone = "Everyone";
        public static void main(String... args) {
            Test test = null;
            System.out.println(Test.everyone); // Everyone
            System.out.println(test.everyone); // Everyone
        }
    }
    Java doesn't care the variable test is null as it is looking for a static variable.
  6. Static member doesn't require an instance to use.
  7. Instance member require an instance to use.
  8. A static method can call another static method.
  9. A static method cannot call instance method without referencing instance of class, even it is within the ssame class.
  10. An instance method can call static method.
  11. An instance method can call another instance method within the same class.
  12. Static variable can be declared with same modifiers as instance variables such as final, transient and volatile.
  13. When a static variable is declared final, the compiler will not assigned it with default value. It must be initialized with a value.
  14. Use static initializer to initialize static final variables. 
    static int a;
    final static int b;
    final static int c; // Compile error as c is final and not initialized
    static{ // static initializer
        b = 5;
    }
  15. Instance Initializer / Constructor
    cannot
    initialize static final variables.
  16. All static initializers run when the class is first used, in the order they are defined. 
    static {
        System.out.println("cp 1");
    }
    static {
        System.out.println("cp 2");
    }
    cp1 will print before cp2.
  17. Try to avoid instance initializer. Use constructor instead.
  18. Use static initializer if initializing static variables uses more than one line. Put all static initialization in the same block.
  19. Static import can import static member of classes. 
    import java.time.Duration;
    import static java.time.Duration.ofDays;
    public class Test {
        public static void main(String... args) {
            Duration duration = ofDays(1); // ofDays instead of Duration.ofDays
            System.out.println(duration); // PT24H
        }
    }
  20. Static import allows you not to specify where each static method or variable comes from each time you use it.
  21. Static import can only import static members.
  22. Static import
    cannot
    import class. To import class, use regular import instead.
  23. You
    cannot
    static import 2 or more static members with the same name. In that case, refer to static member via their class name.

Pass by value​

  1. Java is a pass-by-value language.
  2. When a method is invoked, it receives copy of the parameter from the caller.
  3. Assignments made to the parameter in the method do not affect the caller.
  4. When passing a primitive, the method receives a copy of primitive's value. 
    static void increment(int i){
        i += 1;
        System.out.println( "Callee: " + i ); // Callee: 1001
    }
    public static void main(String... args) {
        int salary = 1000;
        increment(salary);
        System.out.println( "Caller: " + salary ); // Caller: 1000
    }
  5. When passing an object, the method receives a copy of reference. 
    static void reassign(StringBuilder sb){
        sb = new StringBuilder("Happy Valley");
        System.out.println( "Callee: " + sb ); // Callee: Happy Valley
    }
    public static void main(String... args) {
       var sb = new StringBuilder("Hello World");
       reassign(sb);
       System.out.println( "Caller: " + sb ); // Caller: Hello World
    }
    Note sb in the main method is still pointing to the Stringbuilder with value Hello World.
  6. Note the above example focus on the assignment of variables, and show that any reassignments made to the parameter in the method do not affect the caller.
  7. When passing an object to a method, the method receives a copy of reference, and that copy of reference points to the same object as the caller.
  8. Changes made to the object will be available to both references (caller and callee). 
    static void append(StringBuilder sb){
        sb.append(" and Happy new year.");
        System.out.println( "Callee: " + sb); // Callee: Hello World and Happy new year.
    }
    public static void main(String... args) {
       var sb = new StringBuilder("Hello World");
       append(sb);
       System.out.println( "Caller: " + sb); // Caller: Hello World and Happy new year
    }

Returning data​

  1. Method can return data. However be careful if the caller ignores the data returned. 
    static String change(String str){
        str += " Wong";
        return str;
    }
    public static void main(String... args) {
       var a1 = "Mary";
       var a2 = "Amy";
       a1 = change(a1);
       change(a2); // ignores the data returned
       System.out.println(a1); // Mary Wong
       System.out.println(a2); // Amy
    }

Autoboxing and Unboxing​

  1. Java will automatically convert between primitives and wrapper classes.
  2. Autoboxing
    : primitive -> wrapper class
  3. Unboxing
    : wrapper class -> primitive
  4. Java can implicitly cast a smaller primitive to a larger one. It can implicitly autobox a primitive to wrapper class. But it
    cannot
    do both at the same line. 
    float f = 1.0f;
    double d1 = f; // Implicitly cast a smaller primitve to larger one
    Double d2 = d1; // Implicitly autobox a primitive to wrapper class
    Double d3 = f; // Compilation error - java: incompatible types: float cannot be converted to java.lang.Double
  5. Unboxing a null value will throw NullPointerException. 
    Double a = null;
    double b = a; // java.lang.NullPointerException: Cannot invoke "java.lang.Double.doubleValue()" because "a" is null

Overloading​

  1. Overloading methods have the same method name but different parameter lists.
  2. Overloading methods must have different method signature.
  3. You
    cannot
    declare duplicate methods (same method signature) in the same class.
  4. Things other than method name can vary for overloading methods, such as access modifier, optional specifier, return type, exception list, etc.
  5. Java picks the most specific version it can when calling overloading methods, be it primitive or reference type.
  6. The same applies to autoboxing when both primitive and wrapper version are present as overloading methods. Java picks the most specific version. 
    static void print(int a) { System.out.println("Primitive method is called.");}
    static void print(Integer a) { System.out.println("Wrapper method is called.");}
    public static void main(String... args) {
        int primitive = 1 ;
        Integer wrapper = 2;
        print(primitive); // Primitive method is called.
        print(wrapper); // Wrapper method is called.
    }
  7. Array
    cannot
    perform autoboxing as below. 
    static void method(Integer[] i){};
    public static void main (String... args){
        int[] i = { 1, 2, 3 };
        method(i); // Compile error: java: incompatible types: int[] cannot be converted to java.lang.Integer[]
    }
  8. Java treats varargs as if they were an array. Method signature will be the same as an array, and lead to duplicate method error. 
    static void method(Integer[] i){};
    static void method(Integer... i){}; // java: cannot declare both method(java.lang.Integer...) and method(java.lang.Integer[])
  9. Overloading order is listed in order of precedence below.
    • Exact match by type
    • Larger primitive type
    • Autoboxed type
    • varargs

6. Class Design​

Inheritance​

  1. A subclass automatically includes certain members of its parent class.
  2. Use the keyword extends to declare subclass. 
    class Parent{}
    class Child extends Parent{}
  3. Inheritance is transitive. If A extends B, and B extends C, then A is also a subclass of C.
  4. All public and protected members are automatically available to child class.
  5. Package members (same package as the child) are available to child class.
  6. Private members are
    NEVER
    available via inheritance.
  7. You
    cannot
    extends a final class.
  8. Java supports single inheritance but not multiple inheritance. A class can inherit from only one parent class.

java.lang.Object​

  1. All class inherit from java.lang.Object.
  2. If a class doesn't extend another class, the compiler will automatically add the syntax extends java.lang.Object.
  3. Primitive type doesn't inherit from java.lang.Object.
  4. Wrapper class inherits from java.lang.Object.

Access modifier​

  1. A top level class is one not defined in another class, i.e. not
    Nested class
    .
  2. You don't have to declare a top level class public. 
    class Test {}
  3. You
    cannot
    declare a top level class private or protected. 
    private class Test {}
  4. You can declare a nested class with any access modifier. 
    class Test {
        public class Nested1{}
        class Nested2{}
        protected class Nested3{}
        private class Nested4{}
    }

this​

  1. Local variable and Instance variable can have the same name.
  2. By default, Java will use the most granular scope, i.e. it will use the local variable.
  3. To use the instance variable instead of the local variable, use the keyword this. 
    public class Test {
        String name = "Peter";
        public void print(String name){
            System.out.println(name);
            System.out.println(this.name);
        }
        public static void main(String... args) {
            Test test = new Test();
            test.print("John");
        }
    }
    Result
    John
    Peter
  4. this
    cannot
    be used in static method or static initializer. 
    public class Test {
        String name = "Peter";
        public static void print(String name){
            System.out.println(this.name); // Compilation error - java: non-static variable this cannot be referenced from a static context
        }
        static{
            System.out.println(this.name); // Compilation error - java: non-static variable this cannot be referenced from a static context
        }
    }
  5. The use of this is optional (if local variable with the same name is not available). When Java encounters a variable, it will check the class hierarchy. 
    public class Test {
        String name = "Peter";
        public void print(){
            System.out.println(name); // Print Peter
            System.out.println(this.name); // Print Peter
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Test test = new Test();
            test.print(); 
        }
    }
    Unless a local variable with the same name exists, it is not necessary to use this to refer an instance variable.

super​

  1. You can refer a parent variable or method with super. 
    class Parent{
        String name = "John";
    }
    public class Test extends Parent{
        String name = "Peter";
        public void print(){
            System.out.println(this.name); // Print Peter
            System.out.println(super.name); // Print John
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Test test = new Test();
            test.print();
        }
    }
  2. Unlike this, super excludes any members found in the current class. 
    class Parent{}
    class Child extends Parent{
        String name = "Peter";
        public void print(){
            System.out.println(super.name); // Compilation error - java: cannot find symbol, symbol: variable name
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Child child = new Child();
            child.print();
        }
    }
  3. Since this already includes inherited members, super is only used when you have a naming conflict via inheritance, and that you need to use the member of parent specifically.

Constructor​

  1. A constructor has the same name as the class.
  2. A constructor has no return type.
  3. Parameter type
    cannot
    be var.
  4. A class can have multiple constructors with different signature. This is called
    Constructor overloading
    .
  5. Constructor is used when creating a new object. This is called
    instantiation
    .
  6. If you don't include any constructors in the class, Java will create a do nothing, no-argument
    Default constructor
    .
  7. Compiler only inserts the default constructor when no constructor is defined. 
    public class Test
    {
        public Test(String name){}
        public static void main(String... args){
            Test test = new Test(); // Compilation error
        }
    }
    Result
    java: constructor Test in class Test <Warn>cannot</Warn> be applied to given types;
        required: java.lang.String
        found:    no arguments
        reason: actual and formal argument lists differ in length
  8. A private constructor
    cannot
    be called by other classes.
  9. If a class only has private constructors, there is no way for other classes to instantiate it. Design pattern like Singleton uses this technique to control and prevent other classes from instantiating a class via new.
  10. A constructor can call one another using this(). 
    public class Test
    {
        public Test(){
            this("Hello World");
            System.out.println("Constructor with no parameter is called.");
        }
        public Test(String message){
            System.out.println("Constructor with String parameter ( %s ) is called.".formatted(message));
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Test test = new Test();
        }
    }
    Result
    Constructor with String parameter ( Hello World ) is called.
    Constructor with no parameter is called.
  11. this() call must be the first statement in constructor. 
    public class Test
    {
        public Test(){
            System.out.println("Constructor with no parameter is called.");
            this("Hello World"); // Compilation error - java: call to this must be first statement in constructor
        }
        public Test(String message){
            System.out.println("Constructor with String parameter ( %s ) is called.".formatted(message));
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Test test = new Test();
        }
    }
  12. A constructor
    cannot
    use this() to call itself. 
    public class Test
    {
        public Test(){
            this(); // Compilation error - java: recursive constructor invocation
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Test test = new Test();
        }
    }
  13. You can use super() to call parent constructor. 
    class Parent{
        public Parent(){
            System.out.println("I am Parent");
        }
        public Parent(String name){
            System.out.println("I am %s".formatted(name));
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        public Child(){
            super();
            System.out.println("I am Child");
        }
        public Child(String childName, String parentName){
            super(parentName);
            System.out.println("I am %s".formatted(childName));
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Child child1 = new Child();
            Child child2 = new Child("Alucard", "Dracula");
        }
    }
