    Result
    I am Parent
    I am Child
    I am Dracula
    I am Alucard
  14. First line of every constructor is a call to either super() or overloaded constructor using this().
  15. Like this(), super() call must also be the first statement in constructor. 
    class Parent{
        public Parent(){
            System.out.println("I am Parent");
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        public Child(){
            System.out.println("I am Child");
            super(); // Compilation error - java: call to super must be first statement in constructor
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Child child = new Child();
        }
    }
  16. Java compiler automatically inserts a call to the no-argument constructor super() if you do not explicitly call this() or super() as the first line of a constructor. 
    class Parent{
        public Parent(){
            System.out.println("I am Parent");
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        public Child(){
            System.out.println("I am Child");
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Child child = new Child();
        }
    }
    Result
    I am Parent
    I am Child
  17. Java compiler only knows how to add no-argument default constructor. It does
    NOT
    detect and add default constructor that have arguments. You must understand how the compiler add default constructor and super().
  18. In case Java compiler
    cannot
    implicitly add default constructor due to absence of no-argument constructor in the parent class, you must explicitly call the correct parent constructor in the child constructor. 
    class Parent{
        public Parent( String name ){}
    }
    class Child1 extends Parent{} // Compilation error - java: constructor Parent in class Parent cannot be applied to given types
    class Child2 extends Parent{ // Compilation error - java: constructor Parent in class Parent cannot be applied to given types
        public Child2(){}
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        public Child(){
            super( "Bob" );
        }
    }
    Compilation error
    java: constructor Parent in class Parent <Warn>cannot</Warn> be applied to given types;
    required: java.lang.String
    reason: actual and formal argument lists differ in length
  19. super() always refers to the most direct parent.

Initialization​

  1. Class is loaded by JVM before it can be used.
  2. Each class is initialized at most once.
  3. Class initialization
    in the following order:
    1. Superclass is initialized before subclass.
    2. static variable is processed in the order in which they appear in the class.
    3. static initializer is processed in the order in which they appear in the class.
  4. final instance fields will not be assigned with default values. They must be assigned exactly once by the time the constructor completes.
  5. final Instance fields can be assigned in 3 areas.
    1. The same line they are declared
    2. Instance initializer
    3. Constructor
  6. Remember final fields can be assigned only once.
  7. Unlike final local variables, which are not required to have a value (be initialized) unless they are actually used, final instance variables must be assigned a value.
  8. Instance initialization
    in the following order:
    1. Class initialization if target class is not initialized.
    2. If target class has superclass, initialize the instance of its super class.
    3. Instance variable in the order in which they appear in the class.
    4. Instance initializer in the order in which they appear in the class.
    5. Constructor
    class Parent{
        static{
            System.out.println("Parent static initializer");
        }
        {
            System.out.println("Parent instance initializer");
        }
        public Parent(){
            System.out.println("Parent constructor");
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        static{
            System.out.println("Child static initializer");
        }
        {
            System.out.println("Child instance initializer");
        }
        public Child(){
            System.out.println("Child constructor");
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Child child1 = new Child();
            Child child2 = new Child();
        }
    }
    Result
    Parent static initializer
    Child static initializer
    Parent instance initializer
    Parent constructor
    Child instance initializer
    Child constructor
    Parent instance initializer
    Parent constructor
    Child instance initializer
    Child constructor

Overriding and Hiding​

  1. You
    cannot
    override or hide private methods since they are not inherited.
  2. Rules for
    Overriding
    an instance method:
    1. Same method signature as its parent method.
    2. At least as accessible as its parent method. Can be more accessible.
      Cannot
      be more restrictive.
    3. Must not throw new or broader exception than its parent method.
    4. Return type must be the same or a subtype of its parent method.
  3. A static method
    cannot
    be overridden.
  4. A static method can be hidden.
  5. When both the parent and the child defines a static method with the same signature, the parent one will be hidden when accessing with child reference. This is called
    Method hiding
    .
  6. Rules for hiding a static method:
    1. Rules for overriding an instance method apply.
    2. If the method is defined as static in the parent, the child must also define it as static.
  7. Method hiding if both methods in the parent and child are static.
    Method hiding
    class Parent{
       static void welcome(){
           System.out.println("Hello");
       }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
       static void welcome(){
           System.out.println("hi");
       }
       public static void main(String... args){
           Child child = null;
           child.welcome(); // print hi
       }
    }
  8. Method overriding if both methods in the parent and child are
    NOT
    static.
    Method overriding
    class Parent{
        void welcome(){
            System.out.println("Hello");
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        void welcome(){
            System.out.println("hi");
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Child child = new Child();
            child.welcome(); // print hi
        }
    }
  9. Compilation error occurs if one is static and the other one is not static. 
    class Parent{
        static void welcome(){
            System.out.println("Hello");
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        void welcome(){ // Compilation error - java: welcome() in Child cannot override welcome() in Parent, overridden method is static
            System.out.println("hi");
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Child child = new Child();
            child.welcome(); // print hi
        }
    }
  10. Variable
    cannot
    be overridden. It can only be hidden.
  11. If both the parent and child defines an instance variable with the same name, there will be 2 copies of variables. The parent one will be hidden if the variable is accessed by child reference.
  12. Overriding a method replaces the parent method on all reference variables (other than super).
    Overriding an instance method
    class Parent{
        void welcome(){
            System.out.println("Hello");
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        void welcome(){
            System.out.println("hi");
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Child child = new Child();
            Parent parent = child;
            child.welcome(); // print hi
            parent.welcome(); // print hi
        }
    }
  13. Hiding a method or variable replaces the member only if a child reference type is used.
    Hiding a static method
    class Parent{
        static void welcome(){
            System.out.println("Hello");
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        static void welcome(){
            System.out.println("hi");
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Child child = new Child();
            Parent parent = child;
            child.welcome(); // print hi
            parent.welcome(); // print Hello
        }
    }
    Hiding a variable
    class Parent{
        String name = "Dracula";
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        String name = "Alucard";
        public static void main(String... args){
            Child child = new Child();
            Parent parent = child;
            System.out.println(child.name); // Alucard
            System.out.println(parent.name); // Dracula
        }
    }
  14. You
    cannot
    override / hide a final method. 
    class Parent{
        final void welcome(){
            System.out.println("Hello");
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        void welcome(){ // Compilation error - welcome() in Child cannot override welcome() in Parent, overridden method is final
            System.out.println("hi");
        }
    }    
    class Parent{
        static final void welcome(){
            System.out.println("Hello");
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        static void welcome(){ // Compilation error - welcome() in Child cannot override welcome() in Parent, overridden method is static,final
            System.out.println("hi");
        }
    }
  15. The above rule only applies to inherited method. Private methods are redeclared, not overridden or hidden. So no compilation error occurs below. 
    class Parent{
        private final void welcome(){
            System.out.println("Hello");
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        private void welcome(){
            System.out.println("hi");
        }
    }    
    class Parent{
        private static final void welcome(){
            System.out.println("Hello");
        }
    }
    class Child extends Parent{
        private static void welcome(){
            System.out.println("hi");
        }
    }

Abstract Class​

  1. You can use keyword abstract to define an
    Abstract class
    .
  2. An abstract class
    cannot
    be instantiated.
  3. An abstract class can contain abstract instance method(s).
  4. An abstract class is not required to include any abstract methods.
  5. An abstract method does not define a body.
  6. By declaring a method abstract, we can guarantee that some version will be available on an instance without having to specify what that version is in the abstract parent class.
  7. The overridden method will be used at runtime. This is runtime polymorphism, the object can take many form.
  8. Only instance method can be abstract. Variables, static methods etc
    cannot
    be abstract.
  9. Abstract instance method can only be declared in abstract class.
  10. A concrete class is a non-abstract class.
  11. Concrete class that inherits the abstract class must implement all inherited abstract methods.
  12. Overriding an abstract method sticks to same rules of overriding methods.
  13. An abstract class can have constructors.
  14. Abstract classes are initialized with constructors in the same way as non-abstract classes.
  15. A constructor in an abstract class can be called only when it is being initialized by a non-abstract subclass.
  16. A method or class
    cannot
    marked as both final and abstract.
  17. A method
    cannot
    be marked as both private and abstract.
  18. A method can be marked as both private and final.
  19. A static method
    cannot
    be marked abstract.

Immutable Object​

  1. Java is an OOP. States are stored in object.
  2. States are, after all, stored in variables. They can eventually end up as an object. A stateful object.
  3. If an outsider can change the internal states of an object, it will affect the functions, operations or calculations performed by this object.
  4. Some people may think, as long as the instance variables are defined as private, setter is not defined, and that the constructor is defined private, outsiders will be unable to control the instantiation process or change its internal value.
  5. The cruel fact is, as long as reference type is involved and that the outsiders hold a reference of internal variables of your target object in whatever way due to whatever reason, even though they
    cannot
    reassign the reference, they can change the content of that reference.
  6. Immutable objects
    pattern is an object-oriented design pattern in which an object
    cannot
    be modified after it is created.
  7. Below is the strategy to make an object immutable:
    1. Mark the class final.
      • So there is no way for other people to subclass your class to make it mutable.
    2. Make all the constructor private.
      • So except via specific factory method or static method, no people can instantiate your class in whatever way via new.
    3. Mark all the instance variables private and final.
      • private isolates the instance variables from outsiders.
      • final does not allow reassignment of instance variables.
    4. Don't allow referenced mutable objects to be modified.
      • Instead of providing outsider getter method to access the reference mutable objects, provide delegate or wrapper method to outsider to read the data.
    5. Defensive copying
      • on the way in: the input parameters passed to constructor for instantiation of the target object will first make a copy inside the constructor. This way, even the outsider may hold the reference of parameter and change its content, the target object is not affected.
        Without defensive copying
        import java.util.ArrayList;
        import java.util.List;
        public class Test
        {
            private final List<String> names;
            public Test(List<String> names){
                this.names = names;
            }
            public void print(){
                System.out.println(names);
            }
            public static void main(String... args){
                List<String> names = new ArrayList<String>(){ { add("John"); add("Mary"); add("June"); } };
                Test test = new Test(names);
                test.print(); // [John, Mary, June]
                names.clear();
                test.print(); // [], the object is being changed by an outsider
            }
        }
        With defensive copying
        import java.util.ArrayList;
        import java.util.List;
        public class Test
        {
            private final List<String> names;
            public Test(List<String> names){
                List<String> copy = new ArrayList<String>(names); // Defensive copying
                this.names = copy;
            }
            public void print(){
                System.out.println(names);
            }
            public static void main(String... args){
                List<String> names = new ArrayList<String>(){ { add("John"); add("Mary"); add("June"); } };
                Test test = new Test(names);
                test.print(); // [John, Mary, June]
                names.clear();
                test.print(); // [John, Mary, June]
            }
        }
      • on the way out: the output return type of the target object will always be a copy. Even outsiders hold the reference of this copy and make changes to it, the original target object will not be affected.
        Without defensive copying
        import java.util.ArrayList;
        import java.util.List;
        public class Test
        {
            private final List<String> names = new ArrayList<String>(){ { add("John"); add("Mary"); add("June"); } };;
            public List<String> getNames(){
                return names;
            }
            public static void main(String... args){
                Test test = new Test();
                List<String> names = test.getNames(); // [John, Mary, June]
                System.out.println(names);
                names.clear();
                names = test.getNames();
                System.out.println(names); // [], the object is being changed by an outsider
            }
        }
        With defensive copying
        import java.util.ArrayList;
        import java.util.List;
        public class Test
        {
            private final List<String> names = new ArrayList<String>(){ { add("John"); add("Mary"); add("June"); } };;
            public List<String> getNames(){
                return new ArrayList(names); // Defensive copying
            }
            public static void main(String... args){
                Test test = new Test();
                List<String> names = test.getNames(); // [John, Mary, June]
                System.out.println(names);
                names.clear();
                names = test.getNames();
                System.out.println(names); // [John, Mary, June]
            }
        }

7. Beyond Classes​

Top level type​

  1. Top level type includes:
    • class
    • enums
    • records
    • interface
    • annotation
  2. A Java file can have more than 1 top level type.
  3. A Java file can have at most 1 public top level type.
  4. Public top level type must match the name of the Java file.
  5. A top level type can only be declared with public or package access.
  6. A "top-level" type establishes a static context because it can be accessed without any enclosing instance.

Interface​

  1. An
    Interface
    is an abstract data type that declares a list of abstract methods.
  2. An
    Implicit modifier
    is a modifier that the compiler automatically inserts into the code.
  3. Interface variable is implicitly public, static, final.
  4. Interface method without a body is implicitly abstract.
  5. Interface method without the private modifier is implicitly public.
  6. Interface is implicitly abstract.
  7. Below 2 interface definitions are equivalent. 
    interface InterfaceA 
    { 
        void method(); 
        int variable = 10 ;
    }
    abstract interface InterfaceA 
    { 
        public abstract void method(); 
        public static final int variable = 10 ;
    }
  8. An interface is not required to define methods.
  9. An interface
    cannot
    be final, as it is implicitly abstract. Also there is no sense marking an interface as final as no class can implement it.
  10. A class implements an interface with the keyword implements.
  11. A class can implement multiple interfaces. 
    interface InterfaceA {}
    interface InterfaceB {}
    interface InterfaceC {}
    class classA implements InterfaceA, InterfaceB, InterfaceC{}
  12. A class
    cannot
    extends an interface. 
    interface InterfaceO{}
    class ClassB implements InterfaceO{}
    class ClassA extends InterfaceO{} // Compilation error - java: no interface expected here
  13. An interface extends another interface with the keyword extends.
  14. An interface can extend multiple interfaces. 
    interface InterfaceA {}
    interface InterfaceB {}
    interface InterfaceC {}
    interface InterfaceU extends InterfaceA, InterfaceB, InterfaceC{}
  15. An interface
    cannot
    extend a class.
  16. An interface
    cannot
    implement an interface. 
    interface InterfaceA {}
    class ClassA {}
    interface InterfaceB extends InterfaceA {}
    interface InterfaceC implements InterfaceA {} // Compilation error - No interface clause allowed for interface
    interface InterfaceD extends ClassA {} // Compilation error - interface expected here
  17. An interface is not initialized as part of class hierarchy.
  18. An interface does not contain constructor and are not part of instance initialization.
  19. Interface is simply a contract. It defines a set of rules and methods that a class implementing it must follow.
  20. When a concrete class inherits an interface, all of the inherited abstract methods must be implemented.
  21. Java supports inheriting the same method from 2 interfaces that have compatible method declarations.
    Compatible method declaration
    interface InterfaceA { void methodA(); }
    interface InterfaceB { void methodA(); }
    class ClassU implements InterfaceA, InterfaceB {
       public void methodA(){};
    }
    Incompatible method declaration
    interface InterfaceA { String methodA(); }
    interface InterfaceB { Integer methodA(); }
    class ClassU implements InterfaceA, InterfaceB {
        public String methodA(){}; // Compilation error - ClassU is not abstract and does not override abstract method methodA() in InterfaceB
    }
  22. You can define an
    Abstract interface method
    with the keyword abstract.
  23. An abstract interface method must
    not
    have method body.
  24. Interface supports concrete instance and class methods with method body.
  25. For instance method, interface supports
    default
    (Implicitly public) and
    private
    method.
  26. For class method, interface supports
    static
    (Implicitly public) and
    private static
    method.
  27. Interface does
    not
    support method with protected access. A class cannot extends an interface.
  28. Interface does
    not
    support method with package access. For syntax and backward compatibility reasons.
    tip
    • A method without access modifier in an interface is implicitly public.
    • A method without access modifier in a class is implicitly package.
    • If Java interface supports package method, it will break existing codes. Adding new access modifier for package will further confuse people.
  29. You can define a
    Default interface method
    only
    in an interface, with the keyword default.
  30. You
    cannot
    define a default method in a class.
  31. You must provide the method body for a default method.
  32. You can override a default interface method in a class that implements the interface.
  33. A default method is implicitly public.
  34. A default method
    cannot
    be marked abstract, as it provides the method body.
  35. A default method
    cannot
    be marked final, as it allows the class that implement the interface to override it.
  36. A default method
    cannot
    be marked static, as it associates with the instance rather than the class.
  37. If a class implements 2 or more interfaces that contain a default method with the same method signature, the class must override that default method.
    • You can use super to choose the default method we would like to use in this scenario.
      irushu.chapter7.Test1
      package irushu.chapter7;
      interface A{
          default void sayHello(){
              System.out.println("Hello");
          }
      }
      interface B{
          default void sayHello(){
              System.out.println("Hello, everyone");
          }
      }
      public class Test1 implements A, B{
          @Override
          public void sayHello() {
              B.super.sayHello();
          }
          public static void main(String... args){
              Test1 test = new Test1();
              test.sayHello();
          }
      }
  38. One important use of default method is backward compatibility.
    tip
    • Suppose a new method is added for an interface.
    • Without default method, existing classes that implements this interface will need to modify and provide implementation.
    • With default method, existing classes will simply use the default methods. No modification is needed.
  39. You can define a
    Static interface method
    with the keyword static.
  40. A static interface method is implicitly public.
  41. A static interface method
    cannot
    be abstract or final.
  42. A static interface method is
    not
    inherited. Even the class implments the interface, the class still need an explicit reference to the name of interface when accessing the method.
    irushu.chapter7.Test2
    package irushu.chapter7;
    interface A2{
        static void methodA(){
            System.out.println("This is method A.");
        }
    }
    public class Test2 implements A2{
        void execute(){
            methodA();
            A2.methodA();
        }
        public static void main(String... args){
            Test2 test = new Test2();
            test.execute();
        }
    }
  43. A
    Private interface method
    , be it private or private static, can
    only
    be declared and used within the interface.
  44. A private interface method reduces code duplication.
  45. A private interface method provides
    Encapsulation
    . It does not expose the internal working of the interface when not required.
  46. You define a private interface method with the keyword private.
  47. A private interface method must have method body.
  48. A private static interface method can be called by any methods within the interface.
  49. A private instance interface method can
    only
    be called by
    non-static
    instance methods within the interface.
  50. An abstract method can
    only
    be called by
    non-static
    instance methods within the interface.
  51. Summary 1
    Membership typeRequired modifiersImplicit modifiersHas value or body?
    Constant variableClass—public static finalYes
    abstract methodInstance—public abstractNo
    default methodInstancedefaultpublicYes
    static methodClassstaticpublicYes
    private methodInstanceprivate—Yes
    private static methodClassprivate static—Yes
  52. Summary 2
    Accessible from default and private methods within the interface?Accessible from static methods within the interface?Accessible from methods in classes inheriting the interface?Accessible without an instance of the interface?
    Constant variableYesYesYesYes
    abstract methodYesNoYesNo
    default methodYesNoYesNo
    static methodYesYesYes (interface name required)Yes (interface name required)
    private methodYesNoNoNo
    private static methodYesYesNoNo

Enum​

  1. Enum
    is like a fixed set of constants.
  2. You can declare a simple enum as below.
    irushu.chapter7.Test3
    package irushu.chapter7;
    enum TrafficLight {
        RED, YELLOW, GREEN;
    }
    public class Test3{
        public static void main(String... args){
            System.out.println(TrafficLight.RED); // RED
            System.out.println(TrafficLight.YELLOW); // YELLOW
            System.out.println(TrafficLight.GREEN); // GREEN
        }
    }
  3. Enum values are considered constants and used with snake case.
  4. Enum values always come first.
  5. Enum provides values(), name(), ordinal() and valueOf methods.
    irushu.chapter7.Test4
    package irushu.chapter7;
    enum Rainbow {
        RED, ORANGE, YELLOW, GREEN, BLUE, VIOLET;
    }
    public class Test4{
        public static void main(String... args){
            for(var color: Rainbow.values()){
                System.out.println(color.name());
                System.out.println(color.ordinal());
            }
            Rainbow violet = Rainbow.valueOf("VIOLET");
            try{
                Rainbow brown = Rainbow.valueOf("BROWN");
            }
            catch(Exception e){
                e.printStackTrace(); // java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: No enum constant irushu.chapter7.Rainbow.BROWN
            }
            
        }
    }
    Output
    RED
    0
    ORANGE
    1
    YELLOW
    2
    GREEN
    3
    BLUE
    4
    VIOLET
    5
  6. The method ordinal() shows that each enum value actually has an int value assigned by the system.
  7. You can use enum value as case value in switch statement.
    irushu.chapter7.Test5
    package irushu.chapter7;
    enum WeekDay{
        MONDAY, TUESDAY, WEDNESDAY, THURSDAY, FRIDAY, SATURDAY, SUNDAY;
        String getActivity(){
            return getActivity(this);
        }
        String getActivity(WeekDay weekDay){
            return switch(weekDay){
                case SATURDAY -> "Go to rest Zzzz on %s".formatted(weekDay.name());
                case SUNDAY -> "Go to play ~~~~ on %s".formatted(weekDay.name());
                default -> "Go to work !!!! on %s".formatted(weekDay.name());
            };
        }
    }
    public class Test5 {
        public static void main(String... args){
            System.out.println(WeekDay.WEDNESDAY.getActivity());
            System.out.println(WeekDay.SATURDAY.getActivity());
            System.out.println(WeekDay.SUNDAY.getActivity());
        }
    }
    Output
    Go to work !!!! on WEDNESDAY
    Go to rest Zzzz on SATURDAY
    Go to play ~~~~ on SUNDAY
  8. You can create complex enum with constructors, fields and methods.
    irushu.chapter7.Test6
    package irushu.chapter7;
    enum AppleProductType{
        MACBOOK("MacBook"), IMAC("iMac"), IPAD("iPad"), IPHONE("iPhone"),
        APPLE_WATCH("Apple Watch"), APPLE_PENCIL("Apple Pencil"), MAGIC_TRACKPAD("Magic Trackpad"), MAGIC_MOUSE("Magic Mouse") ;
        private String name;
        private AppleProductType(String name){
            this.name= name;
        }
        public String getName(){
            return name;
        }
    }
    enum MyAppleDevice{
        IPHONE_14_PLUS(AppleProductType.IPHONE, "14 Plus", "Black"),
        IPAD_AIR_3(AppleProductType.IPAD, "Air Generation 3", "Space Grey"),
        MACBOOK_M2(AppleProductType.MACBOOK, "M2 Pro", "Silver"),
        APPLE_PENCIL_1(AppleProductType.APPLE_PENCIL, "1", "White"){
            public String getDescription(){
                return """
                    ================================================================
                    Apple Product Type : %s
                        Apple Model No : %s""".formatted(productType.getName(), modelNo);
            }
        };
        // Fields
        protected AppleProductType productType;
        protected String modelNo;
        protected String color;
        // Constructor
        private MyAppleDevice(AppleProductType productType, String modelNo, String color){
            this.productType = productType;
            this.modelNo = modelNo;
            this.color = color;
        }
        // Methods
        public String getDescription(){
            return """
                    ================================================================
                    Apple Product Type : %s
                        Apple Model No : %s
                                Color : %s""".formatted(productType.getName(), modelNo, color);
        }
    }
    public class Test6 {
        public static void main(String... args){
            for(var myAppleDevice: MyAppleDevice.values()){
                System.out.println(myAppleDevice.getDescription());
            }
        }
    }
    Output
    ================================================================
    Apple Product Type : iPhone
        Apple Model No : 14 Plus
                Color : Black
    ================================================================
    Apple Product Type : iPad
        Apple Model No : Air Generation 3
                Color : Space Grey
    ================================================================
    Apple Product Type : MacBook
        Apple Model No : M2 Pro
                Color : Silver
    ================================================================
    Apple Product Type : Apple Pencil
        Apple Model No : 1
  9. You can define abstract method for enum.
  10. An enum can implement interface.
